prior_works.title: Optimal Mechanism Design and Money Burning
prior_works.role: Baseline objective/benchmark and tight gap for i.i.d. n bidders, m identical items
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work established the information-robust approach of maximizing (buyer) utility via welfare as an upper bound and proved the Θ(1+log(n/m)) welfare–utility gap for i.i.d. agents with m identical items; the present paper explicitly extends this program to the multidimensional unit-demand setting and matches the same tight dependence via a reduction back to the identical-items case.

prior_works.title: Multi-parameter Mechanism Design and Sequential Posted Pricing
prior_works.authors: Shuchi Chawla, Jason D. Hartline, David Malec, Balasubramanian Sivan
prior_works.role: Simple, prior-independent posted-price mechanisms for multi-dimensional unit-demand
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s use of simple, prior-independent mechanisms for multidimensional unit-demand environments builds directly on sequential posted pricing frameworks introduced here, adapting them to target welfare as a benchmark for utility maximization.

prior_works.title: Revenue Maximization with a Single Sample
prior_works.authors: Pinyan Dhangwatnotai, Tim Roughgarden, Qiqi Yan
prior_works.role: Prior-independence methodology and welfare-benchmarking via posted prices
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors’ prior-independent techniques and welfare-based upper-bounding via posted prices underpin this paper’s information-robust design goals, informing how to approximate an optimal benchmark without distributional knowledge.

prior_works.title: Matroid Prophet Inequalities
prior_works.role: 1−1/e-type constant-factor guarantees for online selection under matroid constraints
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The (1−1/e)-style prophet inequality guarantees for structured feasibility constraints motivate the paper’s (1−1/e)-approximation when items exceed buyers, where unit-demand feasibility can be cast into a matroid/matching framework amenable to posted-price implementations.

prior_works.title: Bayesian Combinatorial Auctions: Expanding the Ex Ante Relaxation
prior_works.role: Ex-ante relaxation and reductions from multi- to single-dimensional settings
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work’s ex-ante relaxation and reduction toolkit enables the present paper’s key technical move of reducing the i.i.d. unit-demand problem to the identical-items setting to prove tight bounds in both n and m.

prior_works.title: An Optimal Algorithm for On-line Bipartite Matching
prior_works.authors: Richard M. Karp, Umesh V. Vazirani, Vijay V. Vazirani
prior_works.role: Foundational 1−1/e benchmark for matching that informs posted-price welfare guarantees
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The classic 1−1/e barrier for online matching provides the algorithmic template and tight constant that this paper leverages (via posted prices/prophet-like analyses) to obtain a (1−1/e)-approximation when supply exceeds demand.

prior_works.title: Combinatorial Auctions via Posted Prices
prior_works.authors: Michal Feldman, Nikita Gravin, Brendan Lucier
prior_works.role: Posted-price mechanisms achieving welfare approximations in multi-dimensional settings
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The welfare-approximation via posted prices in multi-dimensional environments directly supports the paper’s choice of simple, prior-independent mechanisms targeting the welfare benchmark in the i.i.d. unit-demand setting.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper advances the Hartline–Roughgarden program of maximizing buyer utility through simple, information-robust mechanisms by moving from the identical-items, single-parameter world to multi-dimensional unit-demand preferences. Hartline and Roughgarden (2008) provide the conceptual and technical baseline: utility is upper-bounded by welfare, and in the i.i.d. m-unit setting the welfare–utility gap is Θ(1+log(n/m)). The present work preserves this welfare-benchmarking lens and shows the same tight dependence in the richer multi-dimensional setting via a reduction back to identical items.

The mechanismic backbone comes from sequential posted-pricing frameworks for unit-demand buyers (Chawla et al., 2010) and prior-independent design methodology (Dhangwatnotai et al., 2010), enabling distribution-robust mechanisms that target welfare without full prior knowledge. To obtain the (1−1/e) guarantee when items exceed buyers, the authors draw on prophet-inequality constants under structured feasibility (Kleinberg & Weinberg, 2012) and the classic 1−1/e bound from online bipartite matching (Karp–Vazirani–Vazirani, 1990), which together justify tight constant-factor welfare approximations implementable via posted prices.

Crucial to proving tightness in both n and m is the ex-ante relaxation toolkit (Alaei, 2014), which facilitates reductions from multi-dimensional unit-demand demand to single-parameter identical-items instances, preserving approximation factors and enabling inheritance of lower bounds. Finally, broader posted-price welfare guarantees in multi-dimensional environments (Feldman–Gravin–Lucier, 2015) reinforce the choice of simple, prior-independent mechanisms. Collectively, these works shape both the benchmark (welfare), the mechanism class (prior-independent posted prices), and the proof strategy (prophet/matching constants and ex-ante reduction) that yield the paper’s tight approximations.
